Text saved: An earthquake is when the ground shakes very hard. Earthquakes can break buildings and bridges. Luckily, bridges do not fall down very often. This is true for new, modern bridges. Engineers now build bridges in special places. These places are in earthquake areas. These places do not move so much.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6904 is below the required threshold of 0.75. This indicates a critical loss of the original text's core message.

- Primary Deviation: The original text states that engineers build on areas that are 'much more resistant to movement'. Your output, 'These places do not move so much', is a severe oversimplification. It changes the meaning from a property of the ground (resistance) to a simple observation of outcome (less movement). This semantic shift is unacceptable and is the direct cause of the metric failure.

- Suggestion: The concept of 'resistance' must be preserved. Rephrase the final sentences to capture this meaning. Example: 'Engineers build bridges on ground that is stronger. This ground does not move easily when there is an earthquake.'
